course_title: Managing Cultural Heritage: Ethics, History and Practice

learning_outcomes.description: Be familiar with the ethics, history and legislative framework of cultural heritage management across Australia and Queensland
Recognise and apply the principles of The Burra Charter to heritage places
Apply Geographical Information Systems (GIS) methods to cultural heritage management
Explain significance-based cultural heritage management practices within a critical framework, emphasising the importance of community
Communicate heritage concepts and findings for a variety of industry appropriate purposes, while demonstrating cultural safety

assessments.due_date:
13/03/2026 - 29/05/2026

Assessments are due at the end of timetabled class in Weeks 3, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12 and 13.
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
You will be required to complete a sequence of class exercises reflecting the week's theme and learning outcomes. The work will be completed in-class and submitted at the end of the class. Class activities will take a variety of written formats, incorporating a combination of groupwork, individual tasks and self reflection.

Each class exercise is worth 10%. There are eight classes across the semester where in-class exercises will be assessed. Your best five scores will count towards your course grade.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.

AI Use: This assessment task will be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment is due at the end of each week's timetabled class when an exercise has been set. You will hand in all work for that week's assessment at the end of the class for the relevant week.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Heritage management briefing document and meeting
assessments.due_date:
Due 3pm 20/05/2026

21/05/2026 - 29/05/2026

Part I (the briefing document) is due at 3pm on 20/05/2026.

Select dates and times will be made available to students to complete Part II. Students will need to assign themselves a timeslot to complete their presentation to teaching staff between 21/05/2026 and 29/05/2026.
assessments.task_description:
This assessment is designed to replicate standard industry tasks in assessing heritage places and communicating best practice strategies for management. The target audience for your briefing document and presentation is a heritage professional working on behalf of the local community of that place. You will provide the guidance that the heritage professional will take back to the community for implementation. You should assume the local community wish to preserve the values of the place as best they can with limited funding. Your management strategies can either offer alternative uses for the site, or work with the ways the place is already being used.

Many of the in-class exercises will provide you with the skills to complete this task; use the feedback provided on those to guide your approach here.

PART I: Management briefing document

Select a place that is NOT on any heritage register, list or overlay at the local, state, national or international levels. 

Visit the place and make first-hand observations about it, including photographing significant elements. The place will need to be accessible to the public or in a place you can freely access. Do not speak with any community members or anyone else associated with the place for your assessment. Your work will need to be supported by some research into the history of the place, but only enough to support your significance assessment and management strategies (it is not the focus of the task).

Produce a short management briefing document that:

1. Describes the place (including its boundaries, community and key visitors, history and site elements);

2. Assesses its significance using the Burra Charter criteria;

3. Proposes three realistic values-based, heritage management policies for the place.

The word count is no more than 1500 words. The format should be a briefing document that clearly and professionally conveys the proposed management strategies for the place.

You must include a GIS-created map to support your work; you may wish to convey the place boundary, heritage elements, significance and/or management strategies as a map. Your brief needs to include a reference list (including image sources).

Your briefing document will be submitted to Turnitin in advance of a presentation.

PART II: Presenting your management plan

To present your findings you will give a 4-minute summary of your brief, followed by 4 minutes of informal questions and discussion about the work. The format will emulate a client meeting and gives you a chance to explain your work, particularly justifying and advocating for your heritage management policies.

You should broadly follow the structure of the briefing document in your summary, focusing on the key parts and your reasoning. You can assume your audience has read your brief. A copy of the brief will be made available to you in the meeting, which you can refer to and guide the discussion. You will not be able to present a Powerpoint or other media in the meeting.


Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.

AI Use: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. You must submit an AI usage statement (template provided in tutorial and on Blackboard). Even if you did not use AI to support your writing, you must still submit the AI usage statement. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assignment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
What is cultural heritage?

We will look at what cultural heritage is, the diversity of heritage and archaeology's place in it. We look at how heritage developed, its legislative context and the central role of The Burra Charter in providing a framework for heritage practice. We also briefly cover what you need to know about the course, with a focus on assessment.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: What is cultural heritage? We will look at what cultural heritage is, the diversity of heritage and archaeology's place in it. We look at how heritage developed, its legislative context and the central role of The Burra Charter in providing a framework for heritage practice. We also briefly cover what you need to know about the course, with a focus on assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
The Burra Charter

The Burra Charter is an important document that forms the basis of most heritage work in Australia. Work through the module at your own pace during the week.

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: The Burra Charter The Burra Charter is an important document that forms the basis of most heritage work in Australia. Work through the module at your own pace during the week.

learning_activities.topic:
Cultural heritage principles

An introduction on how we 'do' cultural heritage management. CHM involves engaging with a set of principles that are repeated across projects, using the Burra Charter we'll explore these steps and what they mean. This week's in-class exercise on the heritage steps will provide the basis for later assessment.
learning_activities.topic_description: Cultural heritage principles An introduction on how we 'do' cultural heritage management. CHM involves engaging with a set of principles that are repeated across projects, using the Burra Charter we'll explore these steps and what they mean. This week's in-class exercise on the heritage steps will provide the basis for later assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
The Queensland Heritage Act 1992 and other planning tools

Watch this online content so that you can understand important sections of the Federal legislation, QHA1992, and local planning tools. Work through the module at your own pace during the week.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_title: The Queensland Heritage Act 1992 and other planning tools
learning_activities.topic_description: The Queensland Heritage Act 1992 and other planning tools Watch this online content so that you can understand important sections of the Federal legislation, QHA1992, and local planning tools. Work through the module at your own pace during the week.

learning_activities.topic:
Significance Assessment

We will explore how to assess cultural heritage significance with a critical lens including guest lecture with Jane Willcock from the Anthropology Museum. We will look at values, criteria and thresholds and learn how to write statements of significance with an in-class exercise.
learning_activities.topic_description: Significance Assessment We will explore how to assess cultural heritage significance with a critical lens including guest lecture with Jane Willcock from the Anthropology Museum. We will look at values, criteria and thresholds and learn how to write statements of significance with an in-class exercise.

learning_activities.topic:
Indigenous heritage and the ACHA2003

Guest lecturer Michael Aird will discuss the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003 and how this legislations provides a framework for Indigenous people to be in charge of their cultural heritage. Although, there are many problems with this legislation, in particular with the processes of deciding who are the most appropriate Indigenous community representatives that need to be consulted.
learning_activities.topic_description: Indigenous heritage and the ACHA2003 Guest lecturer Michael Aird will discuss the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003 and how this legislations provides a framework for Indigenous people to be in charge of their cultural heritage. Although, there are many problems with this legislation, in particular with the processes of deciding who are the most appropriate Indigenous community representatives that need to be consulted.

learning_activities.topic:
Anthropology Museum visit (on campus)

For the second portion of this week's seminar, we will walk to the Anthropology Museum for a special viewing and group discussion of the new exhibition Shields: Design and Functionality. Information from this visit (or from the Queensland Museum in Week 6) provides the basis for the in-class exercise in Week 7.
learning_activities.topic_description: Anthropology Museum visit (on campus) For the second portion of this week's seminar, we will walk to the Anthropology Museum for a special viewing and group discussion of the new exhibition Shields: Design and Functionality. Information from this visit (or from the Queensland Museum in Week 6) provides the basis for the in-class exercise in Week 7.

learning_activities.topic:
Communities and stakeholders

This week we will examine connecting heritage to who it matters, by exploring co-design and community led projects. This week's in-class exercise will consider understanding the potential conflicts between community and stakeholders (and technical roles in navigating this space).
learning_activities.topic_description: Communities and stakeholders This week we will examine connecting heritage to who it matters, by exploring co-design and community led projects. This week's in-class exercise will consider understanding the potential conflicts between community and stakeholders (and technical roles in navigating this space).

learning_activities.topic:
Queensland Museum Kurilpa visit

This week we will meet at the Queensland Museum Kurilpa for a special viewing and discussion of un/Tethered with curator Imelda Miller. Information from this visit (or Queensland Museum in Week 6) provides the basis for the in-class exercise in Week 7.
learning_activities.topic_description: Queensland Museum Kurilpa visit This week we will meet at the Queensland Museum Kurilpa for a special viewing and discussion of un/Tethered with curator Imelda Miller. Information from this visit (or Queensland Museum in Week 6) provides the basis for the in-class exercise in Week 7.

learning_activities.topic:
GIS module 1: Introduction to GIS

Module 1 of 3 on QGIS. Work through the module at your own pace during the week. The Week 9 exercise will build on the skills you gain in these modules and give you the tools to complete your final assessment.

Learning outcomes: L03
learning_activities.topic_description: GIS module 1: Introduction to GIS Module 1 of 3 on QGIS. Work through the module at your own pace during the week. The Week 9 exercise will build on the skills you gain in these modules and give you the tools to complete your final assessment.

learning_activities.topic: Mid Semester Break
learning_activities.topic_description: Mid Semester Break

learning_activities.topic:
Interpretation and heritage outcomes

We will look at understanding public heritage spaces, exploring different types of heritage outcomes, interpretation, and some of the practicalities of managing our heritage assets (e.g. funding and resourcing constraints). This weeks in-class exercise will use the notes you made in a museum visit from Weeks 4 or 6 to build on your understanding of the five heritage steps. 

Learning outcomes: L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Interpretation and heritage outcomes We will look at understanding public heritage spaces, exploring different types of heritage outcomes, interpretation, and some of the practicalities of managing our heritage assets (e.g. funding and resourcing constraints). This weeks in-class exercise will use the notes you made in a museum visit from Weeks 4 or 6 to build on your understanding of the five heritage steps.

learning_activities.topic:
GIS module 2: CHM and GIS data

Module 2 of 3 on QGIS. Work through the module at your own pace during the week. The Week 9 exercise will build on the skills you gain in these modules and give you the tools to complete your final assessment.

Learning outcomes: L03
learning_activities.topic_description: GIS module 2: CHM and GIS data Module 2 of 3 on QGIS. Work through the module at your own pace during the week. The Week 9 exercise will build on the skills you gain in these modules and give you the tools to complete your final assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Communicating Heritage

Reports, presentations and client meetings: how do we use communication tools effectively in CHM? We'll spend time this week engaging with report formats, and in an in-class exercise how AI can or could be used (or not) to support your work. This week's class will help you understand the format of the final assessment.

Learning outcomes: L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Communicating Heritage Reports, presentations and client meetings: how do we use communication tools effectively in CHM? We'll spend time this week engaging with report formats, and in an in-class exercise how AI can or could be used (or not) to support your work. This week's class will help you understand the format of the final assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Cultural landscapes:

What is a cultural landscape and why are they so important? We'll also explore how do we use the tools and building blocks of heritage management (e.g. GIS, site inventories, listings, legislation) to map, engage with and manage cultural landscapes. This week's in-class exercise will use QGIS, building on the skills you have learnt so far in the modules.
learning_activities.topic_description: Cultural landscapes: What is a cultural landscape and why are they so important? We'll also explore how do we use the tools and building blocks of heritage management (e.g. GIS, site inventories, listings, legislation) to map, engage with and manage cultural landscapes. This week's in-class exercise will use QGIS, building on the skills you have learnt so far in the modules.

learning_activities.topic:
GIS module 3: Making maps

Module 3 of 3 on QGIS. Work through the module at your own pace during the week. This week's exercise will build on the skills you gain in these modules and give you the tools to complete your final assessment.

Learning outcomes: L03
learning_activities.topic_description: GIS module 3: Making maps Module 3 of 3 on QGIS. Work through the module at your own pace during the week. This week's exercise will build on the skills you gain in these modules and give you the tools to complete your final assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Who owns heritage?

Who owns heritage? We will explore the different roles of heritage specialists, what is a heritage narrative, who tells stories and why. In this week's in-class exercise we consider how we can write engaging stories that are perhaps not our own.
learning_activities.topic_description: Who owns heritage? Who owns heritage? We will explore the different roles of heritage specialists, what is a heritage narrative, who tells stories and why. In this week's in-class exercise we consider how we can write engaging stories that are perhaps not our own.

learning_activities.topic:
Being in landscapes: Moorooka Aboriginal Camp

In the context of 'desktop assessment' and the digital age of data accessibility, we'll explore what defines a 'place' and how visiting places and talking to community is critical to understanding cultural heritage. Clear and authentic communication is a critical element to site visits that will also be a central theme to this week's excursion.
learning_activities.topic_description: Being in landscapes: Moorooka Aboriginal Camp In the context of 'desktop assessment' and the digital age of data accessibility, we'll explore what defines a 'place' and how visiting places and talking to community is critical to understanding cultural heritage. Clear and authentic communication is a critical element to site visits that will also be a central theme to this week's excursion.

learning_activities.topic:
Critical heritage studies

We reflect on the origins of CHM and the impacts of that and explore some critical approaches to heritage. In this week's in-class exercise we will consider Authorised Heritage Discourse and its use in understanding our authorising heritage environment.
learning_activities.topic_description: Critical heritage studies We reflect on the origins of CHM and the impacts of that and explore some critical approaches to heritage. In this week's in-class exercise we will consider Authorised Heritage Discourse and its use in understanding our authorising heritage environment.

learning_activities.topic:
Working in cultural heritage

We explore the ethics of heritage and career options. In this week's in-class exercise we will establish our own heritage values to guide future work.
learning_activities.topic_description: Working in cultural heritage We explore the ethics of heritage and career options. In this week's in-class exercise we will establish our own heritage values to guide future work.
